author: By Anton Troianovski and Andrew Higgins
title: Pro-Navalny Protests Sweep Russia in Challenge to Putin
description: The protests moved across time zones and more than 3,000 people were arrested in at least 109 cities, signaling widespread fatigue with the corruption-plagued political order presided over by President Vladimir V. Putin.
content: MOSCOW — From the frozen streets of Russia’s Far East and Siberia to the grand plazas of Moscow and St. Petersburg, tens of thousands of Russians rallied in support of the jailed opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny on Saturday in the biggest nationwide showdown in years between the Kremlin and its opponents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Black, Deaf and Extremely Online
description: On TikTok and in virtual hangouts, a younger generation is sharing the origins and nuances of Black American Sign Language, a rich variation of ASL that scholars say has been overlooked for too long.
content: “I have to make sure my hands are not ashy before I sign,” Nakia Smith, who is deaf, explained to her nearly 400,000 followers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: In Biden’s Catholic Faith, an Ascendant Liberal Christianity
description: President Biden, perhaps the most religiously observant commander in chief in half a century, speaks of how his Catholic faith grounds his life and his policies.
content: Hours before President Biden took the oath of office, he entered the front pew of the Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle, the seat of Catholic Washington, and beheld the mosaics behind the altar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Berkman
title: A Hockey League Is Coming Back, for Two Weeks Only
description: The National Women’s Hockey League, which has been shut down since March because of the coronavirus pandemic, will begin its very brief sixth season with a new team and a deal to have its playoffs broadcast on NBC Sports.
content: The National Women’s Hockey League is returning to the ice on Saturday for a brief season — a teaser of sorts — a mere 14 days intended to remind fans and potential sponsors of what has been missing for the past 10 months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Biden’s Education Department moves to cut ties with an accrediting body linked to a fraud scandal.
description: The Biden administration’s Education Department is moving to cut ties with an organization that was thrown a life raft under the Trump administration even though it was at the center of an enormous fraud scandal related to for-profit colleges.
content: The Biden administration’s Education Department is moving to cut ties with an organization that was thrown a life raft under the Trump administration even though it was at the center of an enormous fraud scandal related to for-profit colleges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Opinion
title: Is There a Small Business That’s Special to You?
description: Behind every one of them is a person who is part of a community.
content: This has been a challenging time for small businesses. The pandemic has forced a lot of owners to close down their physical storefronts, and it’s unclear how many businesses will survive the coming months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: The Lure of Executive Orders: Easy to Implement, but Just as Easy to Cancel
description: President Donald Trump came to rely on executive action for many of his achievements. But his successor seems to understand that it is best used to repeal someone else’s legacy, not build his own.
content: WASHINGTON — As President Donald J. Trump boarded the plane to Florida on Wednesday, he cast his achievements as sweeping, ambitious and, above all, enduring — a few hours before his successor began demolishing that legacy at breakneck speed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin P. Clarke
title: A New Era of Far-Right Violence
description: The imagery of the Capitol siege will have enduring resonance.
content: The storming of the Capitol on Jan. 6 by a rabid mob of Donald Trump supporters resulted in a failed insurrection. But for far-right extremists, including anti-government militias, white supremacists and violent conspiracy theorists, nothing about the insurrection was a failure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: Andrew J. Reis delivers 2021’s Baby New Year Panda.
content: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS — Today we have a varied, entertaining but somewhat gentle entree into this year’s cryptic puzzles. I’m not saying it’s easy! Sometimes there are scads of very improvisational, hard-to-define clues and entries in a “Panda” puzzle; today we just have a few, sprinkled among a terrific range of cryptic clues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Gottlieb
title: Harold Bloom Is Dead. But His ‘Rage for Reading’ Is Undiminished.
description: Robert Gottlieb considers the celebrated Yale critic on the occasion of his last, posthumously published book, “The Bright Book of Life,” which revisits the novels that inspired his passion and awe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt, Maggie Haberman and William K. Rashbaum
title: Trump’s Last-Minute Pardon Frees Man Still Facing Accusations of Violence
description: Jonathan Braun’s 10-year sentence for running a drug ring was commuted by the departing president. The White House did not mention that he faces separate accusations of violence and threats.
content: President Donald J. Trump’s late-night commutation of a 10-year prison sentence being served by a drug smuggler named Jonathan Braun made the action sound almost routine. The White House said only that upon his release, Mr. Braun would “seek employment to support his wife and children.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: A Decade On, Silence Fills Egypt’s Field of Broken Dreams
description: In 2011, Tahrir Square was at the vanguard of popular uprisings known as the Arab Spring. But hopes for a democratic Egypt were crushed and the historic square given a sterile new look.
content: CAIRO — The last guest had checked out, leaving Ahmed Taha sitting on an unmade bed in a deserted room amid rumpled sheets and half-drunk coffee cups, contemplating his future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman and Shaila Dewan
title: Inside the Deadly Capitol Shooting
description: With a mob approaching, a police lieutenant fatally shot a woman trying to vault through a window near the House Chamber.
content: WASHINGTON — During the four-and-a-half-hour attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, one of the moments when the mob came closest to the lawmakers they were pursuing took place just after 2:30 p.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucy Tompkins
title: ‘An incredible scale of tragedy’: The U.S. records 25 million virus cases.
description: Experts say that as staggering as that figure is, it significantly understates the true number of people in the country who have been infected and the scope of the nation’s failure to contain the spread of the virus.
content: The United States has recorded 25 million coronavirus cases, reaching the threshold Saturday afternoon, according to a New York Times database.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian Friedman and Lauren Hirsch
title: Help With Vaccination Push Comes From Unexpected Businesses
description: Microsoft, Starbucks and Amazon are among the companies offering the government assistance with logistics and operations.
content: Amazon wrote to President Biden on Thursday offering to assist with communication and technology. Microsoft is opening up its largely empty office campus as a vaccination center as part of a broader partnership with the State of Washington. Starbucks is assigning workers from its operations and analytics departments to help design vaccination sites, donating the labor to the same state while continuing to pay employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ty McCormick
title: The ‘Muslim Ban’ Is Over. The Harm Lives On.
description: Biden has rescinded Trump’s travel restrictions, but it will take years to undo the damage.
content: On May 30, 2019, Mohamed Abdulrahman Ahmed should have been in class preparing for exams. Instead, neighbors found the gifted high school senior hanging lifeless from a beam in his home in the Dadaab refugee camp in northeastern Kenya. He had taken his own life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Is President Biden Ready for the New Senate?
description: Mr. Biden, a man of old Washington, might be in for a rude awakening.
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: How Newsmakers and News Hosts Are Remembering Larry King
description: CNN colleagues like Wolf Blitzer and Christiane Amanpour were joined by celebrities including Oprah Winfrey, Bill Clinton, Magic Johnson and Celine Dion in mourning the longtime broadcaster.
content: Celebrities, news anchors and politicians were among the many people remembering Larry King, the host of the CNN program “Larry King Live,” who died on Saturday at 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: How Doug Ducey, Arizona’s Republican Governor, Views His Party After Trump
description: Mr. Ducey, who is facing censure by his state party on Saturday, says the divisions within the Republican Party are nothing new.
content: Gov. Doug Ducey of Arizona drew criticism from some fellow Republicans in November for what in other years would merely be routine: certifying the state’s election. But it was only the second time a Democratic presidential candidate had won the state in 50 years, and many Republicans supported former President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to subvert the results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Here’s what we know about the lawsuit McGregor faces in Ireland.
description: For more than a year, Conor McGregor was under investigation in Ireland, his home country, after a woman accused him of rape. He was not charged criminally, but this week the woman filed a lawsuit. Here is where the case stands:
content: For more than a year, Conor McGregor was under investigation in Ireland, his home country, after a woman accused him of rape. He was not charged criminally, but this week the woman filed a lawsuit. Here is where the case stands:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: High School Grades Could Be Worth $100,000. Time to Tell Your Child?
description: Most colleges and universities now use a “merit” aid strategy to solicit teenagers. Your eighth grader probably ought to know how it works.
content: Financial aid is no longer just about what you earn and what you have. It’s also about your children and what they do — and that means that good grades can be worth a whole lot of money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren DePino
title: How to Tell If Your Parents Are in Love
description: For one thing, you might notice how all their bickering melts away during a single moment, like during a slow dance or a sunset. Still, after 57 years.
content: When I was growing up, I could never tell if my parents were wildly in love or careening toward divorce. I awoke some mornings to the noise of their voices climbing, straining to make out their words from two rooms away. Other times I’d catch them planted in the middle of the couch watching “Moonstruck,” their hair back then ink-dark like Cher’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: If Poor Countries Go Unvaccinated, a Study Says, Rich Ones Will Pay
description: A failure to distribute the Covid-19 vaccine in poor nations will worsen economic damage, with half the costs borne by wealthy countries, new research shows.
content: In monopolizing the supply of vaccines against Covid-19, wealthy nations are threatening more than a humanitarian catastrophe: The resulting economic devastation will hit affluent countries nearly as hard as those in the developing world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Methven
title: How to Take a Walk
description: I have a heart monitor. I have a pulse oximeter. I have an oxygen tank. It’s going to be a relaxing stroll.
content: I’m going for a walk. It’s a brisk morning. The sun is shining; it’s a beautiful winter day. I have my N95 mask. I have my bottle of hand sanitizer. I’m wearing a polyurethane laminate jacket over a fluid-resistant surgical gown over a Kevlar vest, all of which is covered by a high-visibility orange safety parka. It will be a refreshing stroll.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: U.K. Variant May Be Deadlier, Johnson Warns
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 23, 2021.
content: “2021 is going to be a cat-and-mouse game to see if we can vaccinate people quickly enough to stay ahead of the variants.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon and Annie Karni
title: Trump’s Pardon Process Was a Mix of Mercy and Favoritism
description: The former president doled out pardons to political allies and friends, but he also helped people serving harsh sentences.
content: Darrell Frazier believed he had found a path out of his life sentence in federal prison, with a president whose allies had advocated a broad use of pardons and a new clemency initiative. Mr. Frazier thought he seemed like a perfect candidate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: What Happens When You Click ‘Agree’?
description: The same legalese that can ban Donald Trump from Twitter can bar users from joining class-action lawsuits. It’s time to fix the fine print.
content: Apple prohibits using its iTunes service for the manufacture of nuclear or biological weapons. Amazon will permit its cloud computing service to be deployed to help combat a zombie apocalypse that could “result in the fall of organized civilization.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Stephenson and Jennifer Medina
title: Arizona G.O.P. Censures Three Top Members Criticized by Trump Loyalists
description: The party rebuked Gov. Doug Ducey, former Senator Jeff Flake and Cindy McCain, all of whom have been criticized by some Trump supporters as insufficiently loyal to the former president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: The Trump Presidency Is Now History. So How Will It Rank?
description: As scholars consider the legacy of Donald J. Trump, it appears that even the woefully inadequate James Buchanan has some serious competition.
content: In the race to the bottom for the title of worst American president, the same few sorry names appear at the end of almost every list, jockeying for last place. There’s Andrew Johnson, whose abysmal behavior during Reconstruction led to the first presidential impeachment. There’s Warren G. Harding, responsible for the Teapot Dome scandal. There’s hapless, hated Franklin Pierce; doomed, dead-after-32-days William Henry Harrison; and inevitably, James Buchanan, often considered worst of all because of how badly he bungled the lead-up to the Civil War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damon Winter and Shawn McCreesh
title: Photographs From the Quiet Inauguration
description: After January 6, the capital welcomed a solemn and safe transfer of power.
content: WASHINGTON — It was eerie, after Jan. 6, when the hush first fell. Troops plodded through posh neighborhoods, and military vehicles blocked some streets. Storefronts remained as shuttered as ever, and then the National Mall became off limits, too. Imperious black fencing already surrounded the White House, and now concertina wire encircled the Capitol. But when the inauguration finally arrived, the silence wasn’t so foreboding. Actually, it was kind of nice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller and Michael Levenson
title: Bomb Explodes at California Church Known for Hateful Views
description: Officials said no one was injured in the attack. The church had been the target of protests over its messages against women, Jews, L.G.B.T.Q. people and the Black Lives Matter movement.
content: The F.B.I. and local authorities are investigating a bombing on Saturday morning at a church in Los Angeles County that had recently been the target of protests for its extremist views against L.G.B.T.Q. people, women and the Black Lives Matter movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: There Are Hall of Famers, and Then There’s Hank Aaron
description: The Braves slugger occupied the rarefied space of a player who stands out in every crowd — even one full of Hall of Famers.
content: It was another day of mourning for Reggie Jackson and the rest of the greatest baseball players who ever lived. Another of their brethren had died, this one, perhaps, the greatest of all: Henry Louis Aaron.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: The Business Case for Boardroom Diversity
description: When big banks see a benefit in helping companies recruit more diverse directors, it’s a sign that there are not just morals at play — there is money at stake, too.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of a big issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: A Quiet Life of Loud Home Runs: Hank Aaron in Photographs
description: The slugging outfielder was a rock of consistency for 23 seasons. He was a superstar unlike any before him — or any since.
content: Hank Aaron wasn’t as loud as some other stars, on or off the field. He was a steady presence, a fixture in right field, a mainstay at the All-Star Game and a terror at the plate. His path was often difficult, and his name is sometimes overlooked when rattling off the greatest to ever play the game. But make no mistake: To his peers — or the closest thing baseball could offer in terms of peers — Aaron was nothing short of a god among men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Joe Biden’s Catholic Moment
description: The new president elevates a liberal Catholicism that once seemed destined to fade away.
content: The inauguration of our second Catholic president was, in its way, a very American-Catholic spectacle. A Jesuit delivered the invocation, the president quoted St. Augustine and paused for a moment of silent prayer just long enough for a quick Hail Mary, and the justices and celebrities represented various ethnic-Catholic inheritances — Irish for John Roberts, Italian for Lady Gaga and Nancy Pelosi, Latina for Jennifer Lopez and Sonia Sotomayor. (It was left to Garth Brooks, singing “Amazing Grace,” to represent Protestant culture.) As America Magazine’s James Keane noted, even Biden’s proposed cabinet is stuffed with Catholic Democrats, with few white male Protestants in sight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: The Maker of the Aeron Chair Grapples with Politics and the Pandemic
description: As the C.E.O. of Herman Miller, Andi Owen has had to navigate a polarized work force while thinking about the future of the offices her company makes furniture for.
content: When Andi Owen took over the furniture company Herman Miller, in 2018, she didn’t expect to get caught up in politics. But these days, it seems no chief executive is safe from the culture wars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Freddie Wilkinson
title: A Summit of Their Own: A Nepali Team Climbs K2
description: A bold winter ascent captures the last great challenge in the world’s highest mountains.
content: It’s not often that a team of climbers attempts K2, the “Savage Mountain,” in winter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: How Alvin the Beagle Helped Usher In a Democratic Senate
description: Senator Raphael Warnock was sworn in this week as Georgia’s first Black senator, and he arrived with a canny canine assist.
content: The dog had a lot of work to do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis and Michael Gonchar
title: Explore the World With These 100 Country Quizzes
description: Expand your knowledge of geography and culture with our short “Country of the Week” quizzes, all based on reporting, photos and videos from The New York Times.
content: How much do you know about Cape Verde? What about Colombia, Bangladesh or Montenegro?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Fresh Starts at the Top in Both Washington and Ottawa
description: A day after Joseph R. Biden Jr. became president, resetting Canada’s relationship with its neighbor, Governor General Julie Payette quit as Queen Elizabeth’s representative as head of state.
content: This week saw two transfers of power in North America. One involved direct, actual power while the other was more symbolic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: ‘We Are Forced to Live in These Conditions’: In Los Angeles, Virus Ravages Overcrowded Homes
description: Perhaps nowhere else in America can the unequal toll of the virus be felt more dramatically. Suburban sprawl and freeways demarcate the neighborhoods of the haves and the have-nots.
content: LOS ANGELES — Betty Rivera was the first in her household to fall sick, early last month. To protect her family, she locked herself in the bedroom she shares with her grandson. Her daughter left chicken soup and herbal remedies of ginger and garlic and rosemary outside her door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Hailey Fuchs
title: White House Orders Assessment on Violent Extremism in U.S.
description: The order for the evaluation from the intelligence community comes as judges continue to deny bail for suspects in the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Friday ordered the director of national intelligence to work with the F.B.I. and the Department of Homeland Security to conduct a comprehensive assessment of the threat from domestic violent extremism, a sign of how seriously the new administration is taking the issue in the aftermath of the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Kurczy
title: Gladdie Fowler, Educator and Mental Health Advocate, Dies at 69
description: Nicknamed the “turnaround principal,” Ms. Fowler was entrusted with low-performing schools in southeast Texas. She died of Covid-19.
content: When Gladdie Fowler was a young teacher in Beaumont, Texas, she once noticed that a student looked sick and insisted he go to the hospital, despite his desire to play in a football game that evening. Doctors quickly discovered he had an ulcerated colon that had turned cancerous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Progressives Are Seething Over Biden’s Likely Pick for Banking Regulator
description: A former Obama administration official is the front-runner to be comptroller of the currency. The prospect has angered groups hoping for more dramatic reform.
content: The internal fight among Democrats about how far left the party should lean has spilled over into the arcane world of financial regulation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Olympic Athlete Speaks of Assault and Breaks a Bigger Silence in Greece
description: Sofia Bekatorou, a sailing champion, said she was sexually assaulted by a top sports official, prompting an outpouring of support in a country where the issue has long been ignored.
content: ATHENS — An Olympic sailing champion has accused a top sporting official in Greece of sexual abuse, the country’s first high-profile accusation of sexual assault and abuse of power since the #MeToo movement swept the world in recent years, bringing down powerful figures in the media, politics and sports worlds.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Everyone Loves This Chickpea Pasta
description: Try Yotam Ottolenghi’s fried tagliatelle with chickpeas and smoky tomatoes.
content: This weekend make Yotam Ottolenghi’s pasta with chickpeas and smoky tomatoes (above), which calls for frying tagliatelle nests before cooking them to add texture. Or try our other top recipes of the week, including Julia Moskin’s chicken Francese and Lidey Heuck’s red curry lentils with sweet potatoes and spinach. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: The New Yorker returns an award for its story on a Japanese rent-a-family business.
description: “A Theory of Relativity,” a 2018 article by the staff writer Elif Batuman, was honored in the feature writing category.
content: The New Yorker has returned a National Magazine Award for a 2018 article about a Japanese business that rents actors who pretend to be customers’ family members. The decision to give up the award came after an investigation by the magazine found that the story’s three main subjects had deceived the article’s author and the fact-checking department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski, Andrew E. Kramer and Andrew Higgins
title: In Aleksei Navalny Protests, Russia Faces Biggest Dissent in Years
description: Demonstrations in support of the jailed opposition leader swept the nation, beginning in the Far East, where people braved subzero temperatures, and reaching the capital. Arrests climbed into the thousands.
content: From the frozen streets of Russia’s Far East and Siberia to the grand plazas of Moscow and St. Petersburg, tens of thousands of Russians rallied in support of the jailed opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny on Saturday in the biggest nationwide showdown in years between the Russian authorities and critics of the Kremlin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Janet Manley
title: Celebrity Pregnancy Is Big Business
description: These days, content begins at conception.
content: The year 1948 yielded one of history’s great non-announcements: an opaque statement from Buckingham Palace that Queen Elizabeth II would undertake “no public engagements after the end of June.” That she was pregnant with her first child, Prince Charles, went wholly unmentioned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Barred From U.S. Under Trump, Muslims Exult in Biden’s Open Door
description: Few foreigners welcomed President Biden’s election victory as enthusiastically as the tens of thousands of Muslims who have been locked out of the United States for the past four years.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — As the results of the American presidential election rolled in on Nov. 4, a young Sudanese couple sat up through the night in their small town south of Khartoum, eyes glued to the television as state tallies were declared, watching anxiously. They had a lot riding on the outcome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: $1 Billion Lottery Prize Ticket Was Sold in Michigan
description: An unidentified person bought the Mega Millions ticket at a grocery store in Novi, Mich. It was the third-biggest jackpot in U.S. history.
content: The winning ticket for a $1 billion jackpot, the third-biggest lottery prize in U.S. history, was sold at a Michigan grocery store, according to state lottery officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How to Make Your Home Fun for Your Confined Kids
description: To make it through these next few months, you may need to make your apartment feel new again.
content: Q: I live in a two-bedroom apartment in Brooklyn. My partner and I are running out of ways to keep our two young children occupied indoors this winter without driving us or the neighbors nuts. Normally we’d take them to indoor play spaces, visit with friends or family or enroll them in gymnastics or dance classes. But we can’t safely do any of that. Any thoughts on how we can make a small space work for rambunctious children?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Pester Playfully
description: Doug Peterson and Brad Wilber are back with a bite.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Doug Peterson and Brad Wilber have collaborated before (recently, in fact, back in October). Their puzzles are very congenial and inventive, and I think their emphasis is on entertaining us rather than making us pull our hair out in frustration. Of the eight debuts in this grid, you get three fantastic pop culture references and two desserts! Crowd pleasers, that’s what I’m talking about.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: What to Watch as McGregor and Poirier Fight at U.F.C. 257
description: McGregor is back in the octagon for the first time in a year.
content: Conor McGregor is set to headline U.F.C. 257 against Dustin Poirier, and the Ultimate Fighting Championship and its business partners would prefer that McGregor, the 32-year-old Irish star, stick around this time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raj Tawney
title: Will Indian Buffets Survive the Pandemic?
description: Eating at buffets, which now seems unthinkable because of the coronavirus, was more formative for me than any bourgeois sit-down restaurant could offer.
content: I drove past a mini mall the other day in my hometown, Commack, N.Y., where my favorite Indian buffet, Kiraan Palace, once stood. My brother, Ravi, and I used to spend almost every Saturday afternoon as teenagers at the corner table, closest to the buffet line, while our regular waiter refilled baskets of garlic naan at our table every 20 minutes. While most of our friends were eating at the pizza place up the block or scarfing down hot dogs at Nathan’s across the street, we held court at our unusual hangout because it felt most like home. And when it closed a few years later, we made sure to find a new refuge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Trump and Justice Dept. Lawyer Said to Have Plotted to Oust Acting Attorney General
description: Trying to find another avenue to push his baseless election claims, Donald Trump considered installing a loyalist.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department’s top leaders listened in stunned silence this month: One of their peers, they were told, had devised a plan with President Donald J. Trump to oust Jeffrey A. Rosen as acting attorney general and wield the department’s power to force Georgia state lawmakers to overturn its presidential election results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: New Pandemic Plight: Hospitals Are Running Out of Vaccines
description: Health officials are frustrated that available doses are going unused while the virus is killing thousands of people each day. Many vaccine appointments have been canceled.
content: As the coronavirus tears across much of Texas, Dr. Esmaeil Porsa is grappling with one of the most formidable challenges he has faced: The Houston hospital system he operates is running out of vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives, Cao Li and Raphael Minder
title: Hong Kong and Madrid tighten lockdowns amid concerns over the new variant.
description: New infections in recent months and a contagious new variant threatening to accelerate the pandemic have prompted some governments to revert to their harshest social-distancing measures.
content: New infections in recent months and a contagious new variant threatening to accelerate the pandemic have prompted some governments to revert to their harshest social-distancing measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Larry King, Breezy Interviewer of the Famous and Infamous, Dies at 87
description: Over five decades, he chatted with an estimated 50,000 people from all walks of life, from presidents and pundits to swindlers and U.F.O. “experts.”
content: Larry King, who shot the breeze with presidents and psychics, movie stars and malefactors — anyone with a story to tell or a pitch to make — in a half-century on radio and television, including 25 years as the host of CNN’s globally popular “Larry King Live,” died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: In Crises, Vaccines Can Be Stretched, but Not Easily
description: Shortages of shots for yellow fever, polio and other diseases have led to innovative solutions even in very poor countries.
content: In desperate times, there are many ways to stretch vaccines and speed up inoculation campaigns, according to experts who have done it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Katie Glueck
title: 10 Republicans Voted to Impeach Trump. The Backlash Has Been Swift.
description: The House Republicans who voted to charge President Donald J. Trump with inciting the Capitol riot are facing a fleet of primary challengers, censures and other rebukes from their party.
content: It’s been less than two weeks since Representatives Peter Meijer, Tom Rice and Liz Cheney broke with nearly all of their Republican colleagues in the House and voted to impeach President Donald J. Trump, but in their home states, the backlash is already growing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Seeks to Define His Presidency by an Early Emphasis on Equity
description: Only two presidents before him have used their first weeks in office to push for equality with the same force, according to one historian.
content: WASHINGTON — In his first days in office, President Biden has devoted more attention to issues of racial equity than any new president since Lyndon B. Johnson, a focus that has cheered civil rights activists and drawn early criticism from conservatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Giuliani concedes that an associate did ask for $20,000 a day to help Trump post-election.
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, former President Donald J. Trump’s personal lawyer, conceded on Friday night that an associate had sent an email to campaign officials asking that Mr. Giuliani be paid $20,000 a day for his work after the Nov. 3 election, but he insisted he was unaware of it at the time.
content: Rudolph W. Giuliani, former President Donald J. Trump’s personal lawyer, conceded on Friday night that an associate had sent an email to campaign officials asking that Mr. Giuliani be paid $20,000 a day for his work after the Nov. 3 election, but he insisted he was unaware of it at the time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: George Carruthers, Whose Telescopes Explored Space, Dies at 81
description: At a time when there were few other Black astrophysicists, he developed a telescopic device that went to the moon on Apollo 16.
content: George Carruthers built his first telescope from a kit in 1949, when he was 10 and living in rural Ohio. Fascinated by space, he devoured magazine articles about space travel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Do Curfews Slow the Coronavirus?
description: A restriction more often used in natural disasters, or to quell unrest, has never been tested against a pathogen like the virus.
content: With coronavirus infections rising and a contagious new variant threatening to accelerate the pandemic, France has implemented a stringent 6 p.m.-to-6 a.m. curfew. Citizens nationwide are sequestered indoors, and businesses must close down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douglas Brinkley
title: A Final Interview With Hank Aaron: ‘I Recognized That I Had a Gift’
description: No matter what happened in America, his greatness still shone.
content: I was born in Atlanta in 1960, and when the Braves moved to town from Milwaukee after the 1965 season, Hank Aaron became my all-seasons hero.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Boris Muñoz
title: Hola, President Biden. Latin America Has a Message for You.
description: Promoting democracy across the region should be the cornerstone in the U.S. relationship with its neighbors south of the border.
content: The image of a fortified Capitol, with some 30,000 security personnel on hand to protect the peaceful transition of power to Joe Biden and Kamala Harris — not from a foreign enemy but from a domestic terrorist attack — demonstrates the main challenge facing the new administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Is an Innocent Man Still Languishing on Death Row?
description: We’ve seen the DNA evidence in the Kevin Cooper case. It points elsewhere.
content: When a neighbor arrived at the Ryen home on June 5, 1983, to pick up his son from a sleepover, he couldn’t process what he saw through the window. He thought all the red must be paint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Anderson
title: Walter Bernstein, Celebrated Screenwriter, Is Dead at 101
description: His movies included “Fail Safe,” “Paris Blues” and, perhaps most notably, “The Front,” based on his own experience of being blacklisted.
content: Walter Bernstein, whose career as a top film and television screenwriter was derailed by the McCarthy-era blacklist, and who decades later turned that experience into one of his best-known films, “The Front,” died on Saturday morning at his home in Manhattan. He was 101.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: 2 Years After Legalizing Cannabis, Has Canada Kept Its Promises?
description: Legal pot has made Canadian justice a little fairer, with “heavily racialized” arrests for possession mostly ending. But vows on amnesty, illicit sales and Indigenous inclusion are works in progress.
content: OTTAWA — When Robert was 18, he was arrested by Montreal’s police for possession of a small amount of hashish, an event that would upend his young life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pranshu Verma
title: Biden Administration Removes Trump Allies From U.S.-Funded News Outlets
description: The Trump administration had been accused of trying to turn the federally funded news agencies into partisan mouthpieces for his presidency.
content: WASHINGTON — The acting chief of the United States Agency for Global Media has fired the leaders of multiple federally funded news outlets, as part of the Biden administration’s sweeping effort to clear the agency of allies of President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: ‘America’s salad bowl’ is fertile ground for Covid-19.
description: Yuma County, Ariz., which produces the lettuce, broccoli and other leafy greens that Americans consume during the cold months, is known as “America’s salad bowl.” Now it has become a winter hothouse for Covid-19.
content: Yuma County, Ariz., which produces the lettuce, broccoli and other leafy greens that Americans consume during the cold months, is known as “America’s salad bowl.” Now it has become a winter hothouse for Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: Six Stars, Six Eclipses: ‘The Fact That It Exists Blows My Mind’
description: A handful of other six-star systems have been discovered, but this one is unique.
content: From star-destroying black holes to exploding comets, NASA’s Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite, or TESS, has spotted its share of surprises since it began searching the galaxy for exoplanets in 2018. But the source of starlight that was mysteriously brightening and dimming some 1,900 light-years away may top all those discoveries for its science fiction-like grandeur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: McGregor’s Legal Troubles Hang Over U.F.C. and His Career
description: McGregor has called a new lawsuit accusing him of rape “old news.” But the case and its wide-ranging implications remain far from resolved.
content: Conor McGregor first met Dustin Poirier in the Ultimate Fighting Championship octagon in 2014. Like so many other McGregor opponents, Poirier, then considered the superior fighter, was vanquished quickly, with a left hook to the head and a series of punches on the ground that prompted the referee to stop the fight in less than two minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Phillips
title: He Allowed Hank Aaron’s 715th Homer and Wouldn’t Change a Thing
description: Forever linked to a legend, Al Downing says Aaron, the Hall of Famer who died on Friday, “couldn’t have been a nicer man.”
content: Of Hank Aaron’s 755 career home runs — a total surpassed only by Barry Bonds — it was the 715th that defined him. It was that home run that pushed Aaron past Babe Ruth as the sport’s career leader, and the abuse he took to get to that point became a huge part of his legacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: Philippine Drug Raid Leaves 13 Dead
description: Officials said 12 suspects and a police officer were killed in the shootout, the bloodiest episode in years in President Rodrigo Duterte’s war on drugs.
content: MANILA — Security forces killed 12 people during a drug raid in the southern Philippines on Saturday, officials said. It was the bloodiest episode in years in President Rodrigo Duterte’s war on narcotics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah Engel Bromwich
title: The Vaccinated Class
description: “Getting the vaccine is the hottest thing you could be doing on a dating app right now,” said a spokesman for OKCupid.
content: The coronavirus vaccine wasn’t supposed to be a golden ticket. A tiered and efficient rollout was meant to inoculate frontline workers and the most vulnerable before the rest of society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Two Trump appointees are being investigated for posting reports denying climate change.
description: The Commerce Department’s Office of Inspector General said it will investigate an incident earlier this month in which two former Trump appointees posted debunked scientific reports denying the existence and significance of man-made climate change, purportedly on behalf of the United States government.
content: The Commerce Department’s Office of Inspector General said it will investigate an incident earlier this month in which two former Trump appointees posted debunked scientific reports denying the existence and significance of man-made climate change, purportedly on behalf of the United States government.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Listen to ‘Nice White Parents’
description: A five-part series about building a better school system, and what gets in the way. Brought to you by Serial Productions, a New York Times company.
content: From Serial and The New York Times, “Nice White Parents” is a podcast tracing the 60-year relationship between white parents and the public school down the block. Reporter Chana Joffe-Walt looks at inequality in education, focusing not on whom schools are failing, but whom they serve. Her five-part series examines what is arguably the most powerful force in our schools: white parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘The Approach’ Review: Three Women and the Men Who Define Them
description: Mark O’Rowe’s intricate, beautifully acted play begs for debate. To start: Why don’t its protagonists have full lives of their own?
content: For an hour I’d sat riveted to my laptop, watching the writer-director Mark O’Rowe’s “The Approach” performed live from Dublin. Then the superb cast took its bow, and I was seized by an impossible urge that hadn’t beckoned me this whole pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Senate Leaders Agree on Impeachment Trial Delay, Giving Biden Breathing Room
description: The plan would put off the historic proceeding until Feb. 9, giving former President Donald J. Trump time to prepare his defense and allowing President Biden to fill his cabinet and begin work on his agenda.
content: WASHINGTON — Senate leaders struck a deal on Friday to delay former President Donald J. Trump’s impeachment trial for two weeks, giving President Biden time to install his cabinet and begin moving a legislative agenda before they begin a historic proceeding to try his predecessor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Murphy
title: America Has a GPS Problem
description: The system is essential but also vulnerable. We need a backup.
content: Time was when nobody knew, or even cared, exactly what time it was. The movement of the sun, phases of the moon and changing seasons were sufficient indicators. But since the Industrial Revolution, we’ve become increasingly dependent on knowing the time, and with increasing accuracy. Not only does the time tell us when to sleep, wake, eat, work and play; it tells automated systems when to execute financial transactions, bounce data between cellular towers and throttle power on the electrical grid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jean Guerrero
title: Biden Must Reckon With Obama-Era Immigration Mistakes
description: Deportations carried out back then left immigrant communities fractured and financially devastated.
content: On March 9, 2016, at the Democratic debate in Miami, Lucía Quiej, an undocumented mother from Guatemala, got up to speak to the presidential candidates. Her husband, Andrés Jiménez, whom she described as a hard worker, had been deported in 2013 after he was caught driving without a license, and she was raising her five children by herself. Her voice broke with emotion when she asked, “What can you do to stop deportations and reunify families?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Beny Steinmetz, a Mining Magnate, Found Guilty in Swiss Corruption Trial
description: Mr. Steinmetz, a French-Israeli businessman, was convicted on charges of corrupting foreign public officials in a bid to reap iron ore resources in Guinea. He was sentenced to five years in prison.
content: GENEVA — A Swiss court on Friday convicted the French-Israeli mining magnate Beny Steinmetz on charges of corrupting foreign public officials and forging documents, in a trial over his successful bid to reap lavish iron ore resources in the West African nation of Guinea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Sugar, Sugar
description: Get hyped for Ross Trudeau’s return and Lucy Howard’s twisty, tasty debut.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — I love the descriptive term “confection” for a puzzle like this one, even though in this case it’s a spoiler. So's the title, and so’s the way that our two constructors sweetly met and started their puzzle-making venture together. Lucy Howard, who’s new to us, constructed her first puzzle last year as an “icebreaker” for her wedding; she met Ross Trudeau (whom we already knew) online, and they made this joint via Zoom. Oh, and they both rock climb, another thing crazy people do. Be careful up there and don’t combine the two sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Senate Impeachment Trial to Begin Week of Feb. 8
description: Chuck Schumer, the Senate majority leader, laid out the schedule for impeachment proceedings against former President Donald J. Trump.
content: Chuck Schumer, the Senate majority leader, laid out the schedule for impeachment proceedings against former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful and Reuters
title: Long Lines as Beijing Starts Mass Coronavirus Testing
description: The authorities in Beijing set up temporary testing sites after a spike in coronavirus infections. Long lines formed as the city tested nearly two million people on Friday.
content: The authorities in Beijing set up temporary testing sites after a spike in coronavirus infections. Long lines formed as the city tested nearly two million people on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Whither the Republican Party After Trump?
description: Readers discuss the split in the party between those who continue to support Donald Trump and those who have regrets.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
